Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the Re Pourghasemi residency test instead of the Koo/Takla test
Application_Facts: Mr. Abbas had discrepancies in his application regarding residence and lacked an 'audit trail' to verify his presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship application rejected due to insufficient evidence of residency
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review dismissed; Citizenship Judge's decision upheld
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged legal error in applying the residency test
Assessment_Factor: Use of quantitative (Re Pourghasemi) vs. qualitative (Koo/Takla) residency test
Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies in Mr. Abbas’s application affected credibility
Evidence_Used: Residency records, application documents, audit trail (lacking)
Application_Basis: Failure to prove 1,095 days of physical residency in Canada
Evidence_Assessed: Residency documentation and consistency of claims
Governing_Rule: Applicant must prove residency under s. 5(1)(c); either Re Pourghasemi or Koo/Takla test may apply if reasonable
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of verifiable audit trail and inconsistent statements
Cause_Description: Insufficient evidence to prove required residency period in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Judge assessed credibility and sufficiency of residency evidence
Evidence_Issues: Discrepancies in residence reporting, lack of supporting documentation
Residency_Compliance: Not met – failed to demonstrate 1,095 days of residency
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation due to inconsistencies in application
Evidence_Assessment: Residency not proven on balance of probabilities
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge’s interpretation and application of the residency test was reasonable
Evidentiary_Issues: Inadequate documentation and inconsistent claims regarding residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard on judicial review; balance of probabilities on residency
